etymology.description: 牜(牛) (niú, 'ox') + phonetic: 肙(玄) (xuán, 'mysterious/deep') = leading an ox -> lead/guide
etymology.interpretation: The character 牵(牽) (qiān, 'to lead') conveys the idea of leading an ox, a common agricultural activity in ancient China. The semantic component 牛(牛) (niú, 'ox') represents the act of leading livestock, while the phonetic component 玄(玄) (xuán, 'mysterious') contributes to the sound.
etymology.simplification: 牽(牽) (qiān) was simplified by replacing 玄(玄) with a simplified component structure to streamline writing.

examples.chinese: 妈妈牵着我(媽媽牽著我)，走在街上(走在街上)。
examples.pinyin: Māmā qiānzhe wǒ, zǒu zài jiēshàng.
examples.english: Mom leads me as we walk on the street.

examples.chinese: 父亲牵着牛(父親牽著牛)，穿过田野(穿過田野)。
examples.english: Father leads the cow across the fields.

examples.chinese: 京剧演员牵着木偶(京劇演員牽著木偶)，演绎古典故事(演繹古典故事)。
examples.pinyin: Jīngjù yǎnyuán qiānzhe mùǒu, yǎnyì gǔdiǎn gùshì.
examples.english: The Peking opera actor leads the puppet to perform a classical story.
